Award.AwardTitle: CAREER / SusChEM: Bio-inspired synthesis of conformationally flexible analogues of the biological oxygen evolving complex: A redesigned approach to manganese cluster molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Synthesis Program will support the research of Professor Michael J. Zdilla of Temple University on the oxygen evolving complex (OEC) of photosystem II that is nature's solution to the most energetically taxing component of solar water splitting. This catalyst is a manganese-calcium-oxo cluster which undergoes structural rearrangements via a 5-stage catalytic cycle whereby it oxidizes water to oxygen, pumps protons across the thylakoid membrane, and harvests reducing equivalents for energy storage in sugars. In this area there is relatively extensive model chemistry of manganese clusters but the rearrangement chemistry and cluster flexibility, key components to the action of the OEC, are not well represented in the literature. Prof Zdilla's research program has two main foci: 1) the design and preparation of manganese clusters of enhanced flexibility via the avoidance of stabilizing chelating ligands, which lock cluster cores in place, and 2) study of reaction and rearrangement chemistry of these systems, especially in comparison to the well-established, more stable chelate clusters.

Global energy demand continues to grow exponentially while fossil fuel reserves continue to be depleted. To meet world energy demands, new solar energy technology must be developed. Nature's selection of a manganese cluster cofactor to achieve the difficult water oxidation reaction of photosynthesis suggests these molecules possess enormous transformative power for solar-powered water activation. The proposed work will pursue these goals in work that affords the opportunity for training of graduate and undergraduate students, and also provides minority training opportunities at Temple, one of the most ethnically and culturally diverse urban schools in the United States. The PI will continue his involvement in science outreach in the Philadelphia area through organizations like the Chemical Heritage Foundation, Nerd Nite Cafe, and the Philadelphia Science Festival. He will also pursue, along with the worldwide crystallographic community, the development of a much needed database of X-ray crystallographic educational resources, accessible to all teachers and students of crystallography, with the aim of providing extensive educational resources for this multi-field discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life on earth is made possible by the ingenuity of living things and their ability to design enzymes--catalysts that promote a desired chemical reaction--tailored to the organism's needs through evolution. Perhaps the most important enzymatic invention of living things is the photosystem II enzyme used in oxygenic photosynthesis in higher plants and algae, which uses the energy of the sun to split water into oxygen and hydrogen, which is ultimately converted to sugars and other energy-rich biological fuels. The first step of forming oxygen gas from water is termed water oxidation, and is the most difficult part of solar water splitting (both in biology as well as chemical/industrial methods). Plants achieve this in the photosystem II enzyme using a small cluster of manganese, calcium, and oxygen atoms. Though we know from biophysical experiments what this cluster looks like, how it works has not been determined for certain. To shed light on how manganese-calcium clusters might mediate the formation of O2 from water, scientists have attempted for decades to synthesize synthetic manganese and manganese-calcium cluster in order to study the reactivity of these small synthetic clusters as a simpler way to understand how plants might achieve this reactions. However, before our work, the vast majority of these synthetic molecules were unreactive and did almost nothing at all.

We hypothesized that we could generate reactive manganese clusters by designing them to have fewer and weaker bonds at the manganese atoms, and that the problem with most synthetic clusters was that they were too stable to undergo reactions. The intellectual merit of our project was the demonstration of characteristics of reactive clusters, and the application of mechanistic tools to learn how those reactions work. Over the course of the award, we prepared dozens of new manganese clusters that exhibit rich reactivity not seen in general classes of manganese cluster prior to our work. These include roles of manganese clusters in cleavage of bonds such as N-N, N=N, C-H, N-H, O-H, and C-N bonds, formation of bonds such as N=N, C-O, and C=O,  and other reactivity such as reversible cluster rearrangements, hydrogen atom transfer reactions, oxygen atom transfer reactions, and nitride and nitrene group transfer reactions. Through our work We have shown how reactivity may be designed into manganese clusters, and demonstrated their ability to perform extensive reaction including biologically relevant model reactions.

The broader impacts of our work has included the training of the next generation of synthetic and mechanistic chemists. Undergraduate students from our group have gone on to graduate studies at institutions such as Johns Hopkins, Boston College, Rutgers, the University of Pennsylvania, and Yale University. Graduate students from our group have accepted high paying industry positions, postdoctoral positions at both companies and universities, and government positions. Another broader impact is the training of the next generation of crystallographers. Three of the students advised or coadvised have entered careers in crystallography, including one at the University of Pennsylvania, one at the Naval Research Lab, and one at Johnson Matthey pharmaceuticals. A third broader impact is informal education in the greater community. This has been achieved via two prongs: 1) Science outreach at local venues such as schools, festivals, and private events. These have included demonstrations for school children at STEM nights, lectures and performances at the Philadelphia Science Festival, Philadelphia Nerd Nite Cafe, and Philadelphia Taste of Science. The performances include demonstrations of chemical reactions, liquid nitrogen, and musical performances of science songs such as Tom Lehrer's The Elements. 2) Generation of free online educational resources for the worldwide scientific community. This has included a repository of educational resources on X-ray crystallography (https://decor.cst.temple.edu/) and an online, peer reviewed, published video on the safe handling of organolithium reagents, highly pyrophoric (ignites spontaneously in air) reagents that pose a risk to safety when used improperly (https://www.jove.com/video/54705/a-protocol-for-safe-lithiation-reactions-using-organolithium-reagents).
